rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]
rev.diff:
Line 68: Line 68:
*Also in 2003, a T-shirt released with the phrase "Everyone Loves a [[Jewish]] Girl" surrounded by [[dollar sign]]s was condemned,<ref>[[Susan Paynter|Paynter, Susan]]. [http://www.seattlepi.com/paynter/158269_paynter28.asp "Fashion statement sends a hurtful message"], ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'', January 28, 2004</ref> though the [[Anti-Defamation League]] welcomed the decision to discontinue the shirts, saying that it hoped "that this experience, combined with another recent controversy surrounding an Urban Outfitters product that reinforced stereotypes, has served to sensitize the company to the sensibilities of its customer base and all ethnic groups."<ref>[http://www.adl.org/PresRele/DiRaB_41/4438_41.htm "ADL Welcomes Urban Outfitters' Decision to Discontinue Production of Offensive T-Shirt"], ''[[Anti-Defamation League]]'', January 9, 2004.</ref> The ADL later expressed "outrage and disgust" at other incidents of insensitivity.<ref>[http://www.adl.org/PresRele/DiRaB_41/4890_41.htm "Urban Outfitters At It Again"], ''[[Anti-Defamation League]]'', March 15, 2006.</ref>
*Also in 2003, a T-shirt released with the phrase "Everyone Loves a [[Jewish]] Girl" surrounded by [[dollar sign]]s was condemned,<ref>[[Susan Paynter|Paynter, Susan]]. [http://www.seattlepi.com/paynter/158269_paynter28.asp "Fashion statement sends a hurtful message"], ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'', January 28, 2004</ref> though the [[Anti-Defamation League]] welcomed the decision to discontinue the shirts, saying that it hoped "that this experience, combined with another recent controversy surrounding an Urban Outfitters product that reinforced stereotypes, has served to sensitize the company to the sensibilities of its customer base and all ethnic groups."<ref>[http://www.adl.org/PresRele/DiRaB_41/4438_41.htm "ADL Welcomes Urban Outfitters' Decision to Discontinue Production of Offensive T-Shirt"], ''[[Anti-Defamation League]]'', January 9, 2004.</ref> The ADL later expressed "outrage and disgust" at other incidents of insensitivity.<ref>[http://www.adl.org/PresRele/DiRaB_41/4890_41.htm "Urban Outfitters At It Again"], ''[[Anti-Defamation League]]'', March 15, 2006.</ref>
â
[[File:Jesus Dress Up magnets.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jesus Dress Up]]]]
 
*The following year, in 2004 [[Jesus Dress Up]], a game created by artist [[Normal Bob Smith]], drew additional critical response.<ref>[[Washington Times]] March 22, 2004 http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2004/mar/22/20040322-092410-2758r/</ref><ref>[http://www.nbc10.com/news/2922892/detail.html "âDress-Up Jesusâ Creator Reacts to NBC 10 Story", ''NBC 10 Philadelphia'']</ref> The company allegedly received feedback from an estimated 250,000 emails.<ref name="afa">{{cite web
